PUBLIC MEETING

A mass meeting of the Settlers of Prince Albert and vicinity will be held on Tuesday afternoon, the 16th inst., at 4 p.m., in the new College Lecture Room, which has been recently built on the Mission grounds, and will be opened for use this evening by Rev. John H. Davis. The meeting will be addressed by the Rev. Mr. Davis.

Settlers' Union

The question of whether or not a Union should be formed among the settlers of Prince Albert and vicinity was discussed at a meeting this morning, and a motion was carried that a committee be appointed to draft a constitution and rules for the proposed union.

RETURN OF THE BISHOP

From a Visit of Ten Years.

His Lordship the Bishop of the Basque of Winnipeg returned to Prince Albert on Friday afternoon after an extended visit to the populous parts of the North-West Territories.

He has been absent more than two months, and has visited every part of the North-West, from Fort Macleod to Edmonton, visiting many places and making good work in each place. He has been very successful in his missionary efforts, and has accomplished much good work in the midst of the aboriginal population. He has visited many places in the North-West, and has impressed many with his teaching and preaching.

THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES

Wednesday, October 10, 1883

THE DISTRICT COURT.

The usual time for holding the annual meetings of the Saskatchewan District Court, which opens at 9 o'clock this morning, has fortunately been arranged so as to hold the proceedings here. We have heard from the Clerk that no warrant had been issued to the Court contrary to our expectations that Mr. Richardson's late judge would be transferred to Regina; but nobody has yet heard of his successor having been appointed.

It seems that something was known about it. We understand that the Court was arranged to be held on the 2d of June last, and by its action we are issued returnable, and just as the last moment word was received from him that he was attached by Governor Dewar, Mr. Bonneville's going had to be postponed, and matters and their witnesses had to be sent back to Regina at an enormous expense. We understand that a difference of opinion among members as to whether the warrants issued for the August Court and returnable ones are good for the October sittings. Some who do not think they are are issuing arrest warrants where others hold them to the old one. There is confusion existing and somebody will have to pay the piper. It is about time that the Clerk received instructions on this point so that there will not be confusion in the coming weeks.

CANCELLATION OF HOME STEADS.

The old system of cancellation of home steads, under which some do not feel they have any claim, has been given up. Claims have been made and "jumped," some have joined, and no doubt the new legislation will ensure that going forward parties to those claims must be held to account.

CONSERVATIVES SPEAK.

A meeting of the Conservatives of Moose Jaw was held on Monday evening, the 9th inst., at which resolutions were adopted condemning the actions of the Dominion Government regarding the land policy. It was also resolved that the government be memorialized by the Conservatives of that place, asking the government to grant an immediate solution of the land question. This has been done extensively on behalf of the government having removed thirty-six square miles for public purposes—an amount of land that is being changed daily at a cost of more than $2,000 per acre.

Although much of what has now become an enormous interest is publicly significant, the situation has become quite critical on the part of the settlers who hold land at a rate exceeding $200 per acre.

This will continue until the land has been removed from the market, and although there are many who believe the land could still be bought at a lower rate, there may soon be none available.

TO BE TAKEN UP.

The Bill King question is to be dealt with once taken over and settled in the manner demanded by the Minister of Justice. He says so in the Regina Leader, and as we understand the matter, there has been a demand that the land be returned at an early date.

The farmer who has bought land at a lower price is the only one who can benefit from this arrangement, and it will be seen that the matter has been brought into focus by the recent events.

THD OLD PRINTER

A printer stood at his press one night
And the wind was blowing loud and wild;
The weary wind was howling without,
And the snow fell fast and fast.

He sat there all alone, with books of snow
And looked at the fasting clock.
He watched the clock as the hands creep slow,
Keeping time with his soul-like tick.

At last there came a type with a weary click,
In his red rose-enameled stick.

His hair was as white as the fallen snow,
And silently day by day
He held them there with grim, like the snow.
One by one, passing away.

The sea was tossing through ferroes deep in his brow.
He heard no sound but this.
And his heart's Roman name could almost
Reply to his grey bearded chin.

And with dignity he sat and wrote on,
Kneeling down with his head in his hand.
He gathered the type with a weary click,
In his red rose-enameled stick.

For many long years, through joy, through tears,
That old printer times "battered face."
And slowly day by day
He held them there with grim, like the snow.
One by one, passing away.

But now there came a type with a weary click,
In his red rose-enameled stick.

And his heart's Roman name could almost
Reply to his grey bearded chin.

And with dignity he sat and wrote on,
Kneeling down with his head in his hand.
He gathered the type with a weary click,
In his red rose-enameled stick.

Manitoba Legislature in Exile.

Winnipeg M. P.'s on the rampage. A dangerous trend.

On Tuesday evening a special train brought from Regina about 9:30 p.m., the members of the quasi-parliament who had been ordered by the government to meet at Winnipeg for the session. Mr. Neepay opened the proceedings, and the North West Council, the Mounted Police, and the Mounted Police, Col. Hartshorne followed and replied for his Mounted Police. Then Mr. Killean proceeded to make a speech, followed by the names of W. White, M. N. W. C. Hayter Reed, M. N. W. C., and Adjutant Murray. Mr. Neepay made a most excellent speech. Mr. Hayter Reed followed, and then Mr. Cotton made a very good speech, fluent and clever. Mean while the other members were talking Charles Lamb, in making some guests to a party. Mr. Neepay made a literary conversation till nine o'clock, then the meeting will continue. In due time the fighting persisted. The speeches were common, and the ladies present continued until the party got on board the train and parted afterwards. There was a great deal of noise among the racks and near the station. Among the episodes was Martin, the M. P. for Portage la Prairie, who spoke at a certain Winnipeg point against a certain Martin, saying that he would not allow anyone to be hanging on and having no right to the name of Martin. Mr. Neepay said, "I will put you in prison if you act this manner." Then Mr. Neepay said, "I will hang on and have the name Martin, and Mr. Neepay said, "I will hang on and have the name Martin, and Mr. Neepay said, "I will hang on and have the name Martin."

COMMUNICATIONS.

BREWERY LICENSES.

To the Editor of the Times,

Sir,—I notice in your issue of the 23rd September, a letter addressed to the subject of Brewery Licenses. I would be glad to express a few of my views on the subject. Your correspondent states that the legislature has no power to make any regulations that shall be sold in places licensed for the purpose, namely beer shops and saloons, and that it cannot be the intention of the Act of a license being granted, but could distinctly state therein, that beer was only to be sold to travelers, and not to housekeeping families for private use only, and not for sale. Moreover a brewer's license contains the brewer's name only, and he may not retail any beer by the glass, therefore a brewer's license does not constitute a licence being granted for saloon purposes.

As regards the Indian population, the lawgiver very severely punished those who committed the offence of them with beer, and although I have known the Indians to go to the brewer's for beer after dinner, they were never found drunk at that time; and although they drank beer, they were quietly told how dangerous it was for them. A brewhouse would be of great assistance here, helping to keep out the bad influences which are so prevalent among the Indians, and would abolish the the use of extracts and essences which are present in such abundance among the Indians, and which would be of great advantage to the unmarred Indians, who have to do their own cooking. If the Indians were provided with a place where they could boil their tea, or if they had a small bag of beer, they would be able to make tea for their own use and that of others, instead of purchasing it from the traders doing the same trade, and thus saving them money. The Indians would be able to save money, and would be able to purchase goods which they could not otherwise afford.

In conclusion, I would say that the brewhouses should be encouraged, and that the Indians should be encouraged to purchase goods which they could not otherwise afford.

Yours respectfully,

E. C.

The Prince Albert Curling and Skating Club.

A meeting of the members of the curling club was held at the office of Mr. Waggner, Tuesday afternoon, when the following officers were appointed: President, Mr. J. Johnson; Vice-President, Mr. James Sinclair; and Secretary, Mr. T. O. Davis. At a later date, Mr. Sinclair will be elected President, and Mr. Davis will be appointed Secretary. Hon. Mr. Macdonald, Vice-President, James Sinclair, and Mr. Davis, Trustees.

The officers were requested to appoint a committee to propose the ground and to select a suitable location for the same. The committee will also be requested to make arrangements for the erection of the new building.

Mr. Sinclair has been appointed Chairman of the committee, and Mr. Davis will be his assistant. The committee will meet next week, and will report its findings to the club. It is anticipated that the new building will be completed by next spring.
